mn32:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying in the sal forest park at Gosiṅga, together with several well-known senior disciples, such as
mn32:1.3: the venerables Sāriputta, Mahāmoggallāna, Mahākassapa, Anuruddha, Revata, Ānanda, and others.
mn32:2.1: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Mahāmoggallāna came out of retreat, went to Venerable Mahākassapa, and said,
mn32:2.2: “Come, Friend Kassapa, let’s go to Venerable Sāriputta to hear the Dhamma.”
mn32:2.4: Then, together with Venerable Anuruddha, they went to Venerable Sāriputta to hear the Dhamma.
mn32:3.2: went to Venerable Revata, told him what was happening,
mn32:4.1: Venerable Sāriputta saw them coming off in the distance
mn32:4.4: Welcome to Venerable Ānanda, the Buddha’s attendant, who is so close to the Buddha.
mn32:4.5: Friend Ānanda, the sal forest park at Gosiṅga is delightful, the night is bright, the sal trees are in full blossom, and divine scents seem to float on the air.
mn32:4.6: What kind of bhikkhu would beautify this park?”
mn32:4.7: “Friend Sāriputta, it’s a bhikkhu who is very learned, remembering and keeping what he’s learned. Those teachings that are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, with the [right] meaning and phrasing, and which describe a renunciate life that’s entirely complete and pure—such teachings he has learned much of, remembered, rehearsed verbally, investigated with the mind, and penetrated well by view.
mn32:4.8: And he teaches the four assemblies in order to uproot the underlying tendencies with well-rounded and coherent words and phrases.
mn32:4.9: That’s the kind of bhikkhu who would beautify this park.”
mn32:5.1: When he had spoken, Venerable Sāriputta said to Venerable Revata,
mn32:5.2: “Friend Revata, Venerable Ānanda has answered what occurred to him.
mn32:5.3: And now we ask you the same question.”
mn32:5.6: “Friend Sāriputta, it’s a bhikkhu who enjoys solitude and is fond of solitude, is committed to internal calm of mind, doesn’t neglect jhāna, is endowed with insight, and frequents empty dwellings.
mn32:5.7: That’s the kind of bhikkhu who would beautify this park.”
mn32:6.1: When he had spoken, Venerable Sāriputta said to Venerable Anuruddha,
mn32:6.2: “Friend Anuruddha, Venerable Revata has answered what occurred to him.
mn32:6.3: And now we ask you the same question.”
mn32:6.6: “Friend Sāriputta, it’s a bhikkhu who surveys a thousand worlds with the divine eye that is purified and superhuman,
mn32:6.7: just as a man with good eyesight could survey a thousand wheel rims from the upper floor of a royal longhouse.
mn32:6.9: That’s the kind of bhikkhu who would beautify this park.”
mn32:7.1: When he had spoken, Venerable Sāriputta said to Venerable Mahākassapa,
mn32:7.2: “Friend Kassapa, Venerable Anuruddha has answered what occurred to him.
mn32:7.3: And now we ask you the same question.”
mn32:7.6: “Friend Sāriputta, it’s a bhikkhu who is himself a forest-dweller, and speaks in praise of forest-dwelling; he himself eats almsfood, and speaks in praise of eating alsmfood; he himself wears rag robes, and speaks in praise of wearing rag robes; he himself owns just three robes, and speaks in praise of owning just three robes. He himself is of few wishes, content, secluded, aloof, and effortful; and he speaks in praise of these things. He himself is accomplished in virtue, composure, wisdom, liberation, and the knowledge-and-vision of liberation; and he speaks in praise of accomplishment these things.
mn32:7.7: That’s the kind of bhikkhu who would beautify this park.”
mn32:8.1: When he had spoken, Venerable Sāriputta said to Venerable Mahāmoggallāna,
mn32:8.2: “Friend Moggallāna, Venerable Mahākassapa has answered what occurred to him.
mn32:8.3: And now we ask you the same question.”
mn32:8.6: “Friend Sāriputta, it’s when two bhikkhus engage in discussion about the Dhamma. They question each other and answer each other’s questions without faltering, and their discussion on the Dhamma flows on.
mn32:8.7: That’s the kind of bhikkhu who would beautify this park.”
mn32:9.2: “Each of us has answered what occurred to us.
mn32:9.4: Friend Sāriputta, the sal forest park at Gosiṅga is delightful, the night is bright, the sal trees are in full blossom, and divine scents seem to float on the air.
mn32:9.5: What kind of bhikkhu would beautify this park?”
mn32:9.6: “Friend Moggallāna, it’s when a bhikkhu wields mastery over his mind; his mind does not wield mastery over him.
mn32:9.7: In the morning, he abides in whatever abiding or attainment he wants.
mn32:9.9: and in the evening, he abides in whatever abiding or attainment he wants.
mn32:9.10: Suppose that a ruler or their minister had a chest full of garments of different colors.
mn32:9.11: In the morning, they’d don whatever pair of garments they wanted.
mn32:9.13: and in the evening, they’d don whatever pair of garments they wanted.
mn32:9.14: In the same way, a bhikkhu wields mastery over his mind; his mind does not wield mastery over him.
mn32:9.15: In the morning, he abides in whatever abiding or attainment he wants.
mn32:9.17: and in the evening, he abides in whatever abiding or attainment he wants.
mn32:9.18: That’s the kind of bhikkhu who would beautify this park.”
mn32:10.1: Then Venerable Sāriputta said to those venerables,
mn32:10.2: “Each of us has answered what occurred to us.
mn32:10.3: Come, friends, let’s go to the Buddha, and inform him about this.
mn32:10.4: As he answers, so we’ll remember it.”
mn32:10.6: Then those venerables went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. Venerable Sāriputta told the Buddha of how the bhikkhus had come to see him, and how he had asked Venerable Ānanda:
mn32:11.6: “‘Friend Ānanda, the sal forest park at Gosiṅga is delightful, the night is bright, the sal trees are in full blossom, and divine scents seem to float on the air.
mn32:11.7: What kind of bhikkhu would beautify this park?’
mn32:11.8: When I had spoken, Venerable Ānanda said to me:
mn32:11.9: ‘Friend Sāriputta, it’s a bhikkhu who is very learned …
mn32:11.11: That’s the kind of bhikkhu who would beautify this park.’”
mn32:11.13: That’s how Ānanda would rightly answer.
mn32:12.1: “Next I asked Venerable Revata the same question.
mn32:12.8: That’s the kind of bhikkhu who would beautify this park.’”
mn32:12.10: That’s how Revata would rightly answer.
mn32:13.1: “Next I asked Venerable Anuruddha the same question.
mn32:13.5: ‘It’s a bhikkhu who surveys a thousand worlds with the divine eye that is purified and superhuman …
mn32:13.7: That’s the kind of bhikkhu who would beautify this park.’”
mn32:13.8: “Good, good, Sāriputta! That’s how Anuruddha would rightly answer.
mn32:13.9: For Anuruddha surveys a thousand worlds with the divine eye that is purified and superhuman.”
mn32:14.1: “Next I asked Mahākassapa the same question.
mn32:14.6: ‘It’s a bhikkhu who lives in the wilderness … and is accomplished in the knowledge-and-vision of liberation; and he speaks in praise of these things.
mn32:14.7: That’s the kind of bhikkhu who would beautify this park.’”
mn32:14.9: That's how Kassapa would righly answer.
mn32:14.10: For Kassapa lives in the wilderness … he is accomplished in the knowledge-and-vision of liberation; and he speaks in praise of these things.”
mn32:15.1: “Next I asked Mahāmoggallāna the same question.
mn32:15.6: ‘It’s when two bhikkhus engage in discussion about the Dhamma …
mn32:15.7: That’s the kind of bhikkhu who would beautify this park.’”
mn32:15.8: “Good, good, Sāriputta! That’s how Moggallāna would rightly answer.
mn32:15.9: For Moggallāna is a Dhamma speaker.”
mn32:16.1: When he had spoken, Moggallāna said to the Buddha,
mn32:16.3: ‘Each of us has answered what occurred to us.
mn32:16.5: Friend Sāriputta, the sal forest park at Gosiṅga is delightful, the night is bright, the sal trees are in full blossom, and divine scents seem to float on the air.
mn32:16.6: What kind of bhikkhu would beautify this park?’
mn32:16.7: When I had spoken, Sāriputta said to me:
mn32:16.8: “Friend Moggallāna, it’s when a bhikkhu wields mastery over his mind; his mind does not wield mastery over him. …
mn32:16.20: That’s the kind of bhikkhu who would beautify this park.’”
mn32:16.22: That’s how Sāriputta would rightly answer.
mn32:16.23: For Sāriputta wields mastery over his mind; his mind does not wield mastery over him …”
mn32:17.1: When he had spoken, Sāriputta asked the Buddha,
mn32:17.3: “You’ve all spoken well in [your own] way.
mn32:17.4: However, listen to me also as to what kind of bhikkhu would beautify this sal forest park at Gosiṅga.
mn32:17.5: It’s a bhikkhu who, after the meal, returns from almsround, sits down cross-legged, sets his body straight, and establishes recollection at the fore, thinking:
mn32:17.6: ‘I will not break this sitting posture until my mind is liberated from the influxes through non-assumption!’
mn32:17.7: That’s the kind of bhikkhu who would beautify this park.”
mn32:17.8: That is what the Buddha said.
mn32:17.9: Pleased, those venerables delighted in what the Buddha said.
